head.title: Superconductivity in a Ferromagnetic Layered Compound

article.h1: Superconductivity in a Ferromagnetic Layered Compound

span.span: Department of Quantum Matter Science, ADSM, Hiroshima University, Higashi-Hiroshima 739-8526, Japan

div.p: We examine superconductivity in layered systems with large Fermi-surface splitting due to coexisting ferromagnetic layers. In particular, the hybrid ruthenate-cuprate compound RuSr2‚Å¢GdCu2‚Å¢O8subscriptRuSr2subscriptGdCu2subscriptO8RuSr POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end GdCu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end O POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm RuSr_{2}GdCu_{2}O_{8}}‚ÄÜ is examined on the coexistence of the superconductivity and the ferromagnetism, which has been observed recently. We calculate critical fields of the superconductivity taking into account the Fulde-Ferrell-Larkin-Ovchinnikov state in a model with Fermi-surfaces which shapes are similar to those obtained by a band calculation. It is shown that the critical field is enhanced remarkably due to a Fermi-surface effect, and can be high enough to make the coexistence possible in a microscopic scale. We also clarify the direction of the spatial oscillation of the order parameter, which may be observed by scanning tunneling microscope experiments.

Recently, coexistence of superconductivity and ferromagnetism has been reported in the hybrid ruthenate-cuprate compounds R1.4‚Å¢Ce0.6‚Å¢RuSr2‚Å¢Cu2‚Å¢O10-Œ¥subscriptùëÖ1.4subscriptCe0.6subscriptRuSr2subscriptCu2subscriptO10ùõøitalic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1.4 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end Ce POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0.6 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RuSr POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end Cu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end O POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:10 ADDOP:minus italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm{\it R}_{1.4}Ce_{0.6}RuSr_{2}Cu_{2}O_{10-\delta}}‚ÄÜ (R=EuùëÖEuitalic-R RELOP:equals EuR={\rm Eu} and Gd) and RuSr2‚Å¢GdCu2‚Å¢O8subscriptRuSr2subscriptGdCu2subscriptO8RuSr POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end GdCu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end O POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm RuSr_{2}GdCu_{2}O_{8}}¬†[1, 2, 3]. These compounds have similar crystal structures to the high-Tcsubscriptùëácitalic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{\rm c} cuprate superconductor YBa2‚Å¢Cu3‚Å¢O7subscriptYBa2subscriptCu3subscriptO7YBa POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end Cu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end O POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:7 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm YBa_{2}Cu_{3}O_{7}}‚ÄÖ except that layers of CuOCuOCuO{\rm CuO} chains are replaced with ruthenate layers. Experimental and theoretical studies indicate that the ruthenate layers are responsible for the ferromagnetic long range order¬†[3, 4], while the cuprate layers for the superconductivity¬†[3].

One of the remarkable features of these compounds is that the superconducting transition occurs at a temperature well below the ferromagnetic transition temperature unlike most of the other ferromagnetic superconductors. For example, in RuSr2‚Å¢GdCu2‚Å¢O8subscriptRuSr2subscriptGdCu2subscriptO8RuSr POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end GdCu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end O POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm RuSr_{2}GdCu_{2}O_{8}}, the superconducting transition was observed at Tc‚àº46‚Å¢Ksimilar-tosubscriptùëác46Kitalic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:46 KT_{\rm c}\sim 46{\rm K}, whereas the ferromagnetic transition at TM‚àº132‚Å¢Ksimilar-tosubscriptùëáM132Kitalic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start M POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:132 KT_{\rm M}\sim 132{\rm K}¬†[1]. Therefore, the ferromagnetic order can be regarded as a rigid back ground which is not modified very much by the appearance of the superconductivity. This picture is also supported by experimental observations¬†[1, 2, 3].

According to the first principle calculations by Pickett et al.¬†[4], magnetic fields in the cuprate layers due to the ordered spin moment in the ruthenate layers are much smaller than exchange fields mediated by electrons. The exchange fields play a role like magnetic fields which act only on the spin digrees of freedom but do not create Lorentz force. Therefore, the present system is approximately equivalent to a quasi-two-dimensional system in magnetic fields nearly parallel to the layers.

However, such Fermi-surface splitting gives rise to pair-breaking effect as well as that due to a parallel magnetic field. The exchange field in RuSr2‚Å¢GdCu2‚Å¢O8subscriptRuSr2subscriptGdCu2subscriptO8RuSr POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end GdCu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end O POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm RuSr_{2}GdCu_{2}O_{8}}‚ÄÜ is very large and seems to exceed the Pauli paramagnetic limit (Chandrasekar-Clogston limit)¬†[5]. The Pauli paramagnetic limit HPsubscriptùêªPitalic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start P POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{H_{\rm P}} at T=0ùëá0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0 is roughly estimated from the zero field transition temperature Tc(0)superscriptsubscriptùëác0italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT_{\rm c}^{(0)} by a simplified formula Œºe‚Å¢HP=1.25‚Å¢Tc(0)subscriptùúáùëísubscriptùêªP1.25superscriptsubscriptùëác0italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start P POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.25 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\mu_{e}{H_{\rm P}}=1.25\hskip 1.29ptT_{\rm c}^{(0)}, where Œºesubscriptùúáùëíitalic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mu_{e} denotes the electron magnetic moment. For RuSr2‚Å¢GdCu2‚Å¢O8subscriptRuSr2subscriptGdCu2subscriptO8RuSr POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end GdCu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end O POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm RuSr_{2}GdCu_{2}O_{8}}, since the exchange field exists in practice, Tc(0)superscriptsubscriptùëác0italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT_{\rm c}^{(0)} of isolated cuprate layers is not known, but it will be appropriate to assume Tc(0)‚àº<90‚Å¢Ksuperscriptsimilar-tosuperscriptsubscriptùëác090Kitalic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP ARG:start RELOP:similar-to ARG:end ARG:start RELOP:less-than ARG:end RELOP:end NUMBER:90 KT_{\rm c}^{(0)}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle{\textstyle<}}}{{\raisebox{-3.225pt}{$% \sim$}}}90{\rm K} from the transition temperature of YBa2‚Å¢Cu3‚Å¢O7+Œ¥subscriptYBa2subscriptCu3subscriptO7ùõøYBa POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end Cu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end O POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:7 ADDOP:plus italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm YBa_{2}Cu_{3}O_{7+\delta}}‚ÄÜ at the optimum electron density. Hence we obtain Œºe‚Å¢HP‚àº<110‚Å¢Ksuperscriptsimilar-tosubscriptùúáùëísubscriptùêªP110Kitalic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start P POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP ARG:start RELOP:similar-to ARG:end ARG:start RELOP:less-than ARG:end RELOP:end NUMBER:110 K\mu_{e}{H_{\rm P}}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle{\textstyle<}}}{{\raisebox{-3.225pt}{% $\sim$}}}110{\rm K} at T=0ùëá0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0 from the above formula. On the other hand, the band calculation gives an estimation Œºe‚Å¢Bex=Œîex/2‚àº25‚Å¢m‚Å¢e‚Å¢V/2‚àº107‚Å¢KsubscriptùúáùëísubscriptùêµexsubscriptŒîex2similar-to25meV2similar-to107Kitalic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ex POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals Delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ex POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:25 m e V MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:107 K\mu_{e}B_{\rm ex}=\Delta_{\rm ex}/2\sim 25{\rm meV}/2\sim 107{\rm K}¬†[4]. It is remarkable that the superconducting transition occurs at such a high temperature Tc‚âà46‚Å¢Ksubscriptùëác46Kitalic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:46 K{T_{\rm c}}\approx 46{\rm K} in spite of the strong exchange field of the order of the Pauli paramagnetic limit at T=0ùëá0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0.

There are some mechanisms by which the critical field of superconductivity exceeds the Pauli limit. For example, the triplet pairing superconductivity is an important candidate. However, from their crystal structures and high transition temperatures, it is plausible that the present compounds are categorized as high-Tcsubscriptùëácitalic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{\rm c} cuprate superconductors and therefore the superconductivity is due to an anisotropic singlet pairing with line nodes, which is conventionally called a dùëëitalic-dd-wave pairing. For the singlet pairing, possibility of an inhomogeneous superconducting state that is called a Fulde-Ferrell-Larkin-Ovchinnikov (FFLO or LOFF) state¬†[6, 7] was discussed by Pickett et al.¬†[4] as a candidate for the mechanism.

On the possibility of the FFLO state, they pointed out that there are nearly flat areas in the Fermi-surfaces in RuSr2‚Å¢GdCu2‚Å¢O8subscriptRuSr2subscriptGdCu2subscriptO8RuSr POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end GdCu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end O POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm RuSr_{2}GdCu_{2}O_{8}}, which favor the FFLO state. It is known that the FFLO critical field diverges at T=0ùëá0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0 in one dimensional models. However, if the Fermi-surfaces are too flat, nesting instabilities, such as those to spin density wave (SDW) and charge density wave (CDW), are favored for realistic interaction strengths. For the present compound, the nearly flat areas are not so flat that the nesting instabilities occur, but the small curvature still enhances the FFLO state¬†[8].

It is also known that even in the absence of the flat areas, the critical field is enhanced in the two-dimensional (2D) systems in comparison to the three dimensional systems¬†[9, 8, 10, 11]. Further, when the Fermi-surface structure of the system satisfies a certain condition, the critical field can reach several times the Pauli limit even in the absence of nearly flat areas¬†[12]. Such a Fermi-surface effect can be regarded as a kind of nesting effects analogous to those for SDW and CDW¬†[8]. The ‚Äúnesting‚Äù effect was examined in details in our previous papers, where 2D tight binding models are studied as examples¬†[11, 12].

Direct evidence of the FFLO state may be obtained by scanning tunneling microscope (STM) experiments. For a comparison with experimental results, spatial structure of the order parameter should be predicted theoretically. In particular, direction of the modulation of the order parameter is important. It may appear that the modulation must be in the direction perpendicular to the flattest area of the Fermi-surface, because then the spatial variation is minimized. However, in some of 2D models, it is not perpendicular to flattest areas¬†[11, 12]. Only explicite calculations which take into account the Fermi-surface structure could clarify the direction of the modulation.

Therefore, the purposes of this paper are (1) estimation of the critical field of superconductivity including the FFLO state to examine the possibility of coexistence of singlet superconductivity and ferromagnetism in a microscopic scale, and (2) clarification of the direction of the spatial oscillation of the order parameter to compare with results of STM experiments possible in the future. We examine a tight binding model with Fermi-surfaces which shapes are similar to those of RuSr2‚Å¢GdCu2‚Å¢O8subscriptRuSr2subscriptGdCu2subscriptO8RuSr POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end GdCu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end O POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm RuSr_{2}GdCu_{2}O_{8}}, because the quantities that we are calculating are sensitive to the Fermi-surface structure.

Recently, the FFLO state has been studied in a tight binding model with only nearest neighbor hopping¬†[12, 13]. It was found that ratio of the FFLO critical field and the Pauli limit is small near the half filling. Zhu et al. have discussed that hence the coexistence of the superconductivity and the ferromagnetic order is difficult except in the vicinity of the ferromagnetic domains near the half filling¬†[13, 14]. However, some experimental results indicate coexistence in a microscopic scale and a bulk Meissner-state¬†[1, 15]. Here, we should note that the tight binding model with only nearest neighbor hopping can not reproduce the shapes of the Fermi-surfaces of RuSr2‚Å¢GdCu2‚Å¢O8subscriptRuSr2subscriptGdCu2subscriptO8RuSr POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end GdCu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end O POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm RuSr_{2}GdCu_{2}O_{8}}. By taking into account the realistic Fermi-surface structure, we will show below that the critical field is enhanced remarkably and thus the coexistence in a microscopic scale is possible in this compound.
First, we define the tight binding model

div.p: with a dispersion relation

math.alttext: \epsilon_{{{\bf p}}\sigma}=-2t(\cos p_{x}+\cos p_{y})-4t_{2}\cos p_{x}\cos p_{% y}-\mu+h\sigma,

\epsilon_{{{\bf p}}\sigma}=-2t(\cos p_{x}+\cos p_{y})-4t_{2}\cos p_{x}\cos p_{% y}-\mu+h\sigma,

div.p: where h‚Ñéitalic-hh denotes the exchange field. When we apply the present theory to type II superconductors in a magnetic field ùêÅùêÅbold-B{{\bf B}}, h‚Ñéitalic-hh is written as h=Œºe‚Å¢|ùêÅ|‚ÑésubscriptùúáùëíùêÅitalic-h RELOP:equals italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| bold-B VERTBAR:|h=\mu_{e}|{{\bf B}}|. We use a unit with t=1ùë°1italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:1t=1 and the lattice constant a=1ùëé1italic-a RELOP:equals NUMBER:1a=1 in this paper.

We take the value of the second nearest neighbor hopping energy t2=-0.6‚Å¢tsubscriptùë°20.6ùë°italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.6 italic-tt_{2}=-0.6t, which gives shapes of the Fermi-surfaces similar to the symmetric CuO2subscriptCuO2CuO POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm CuO_{2}} barrel Fermi-surfaces obtained by Pickett et al.¬†[4] at n=1.1ùëõ1.1italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.1n=1.1 as shown in Fig.1. Here, nùëõitalic-nn is the electron number par a site.

img.figcaption: Figure 1: Fermi-surface of the present model Hamiltonian for t2=-0.6subscriptùë°20.6italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.6t_{2}=-0.6 and n=1.1ùëõ1.1italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.1n=1.1.

div.p: We calculate the critical field in the ground state for n=0.92‚àº2ùëõ0.92similar-to2italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.92 RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:2n=0.92\sim 2, applying a formula developed in our previous papers¬†[11, 12]. For anisotropic pairing

math.alttext: \Delta({\hat{{\bf p}}},{{\bf r}})=\Delta_{\alpha}\gamma_{\alpha}({\hat{{\bf p}% }})\,{\rm e}^{{\rm i}{{\bf q}}\cdot{{\bf r}}}

The pairing interaction is assumed to have a form

div.p: In particular, for dùëëitalic-dd-wave pairing, we use a model with

In our previous papers, it was shown that the qualitative and semi-quantitative results are not sensitive to details of the form of Œ≥d‚Å¢(ùê©^)subscriptùõæùëë^ùê©italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OVERACCENT:hat ARG:start bold-p ARG:end CLOSE:)\gamma_{d}({\hat{{\bf p}}})¬†[11, 12]. div.p: with an average on the Fermi-surface

semantics.annotation: OPEN:langle ID:cdots CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals INTOP:integral FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start d italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start VERTBAR:parallel-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-pi ARG:end FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start VERTBAR:parallel-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start italic-N OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) ARG:end OPEN:( ID:cdots CLOSE:) RELOP:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP ARG:start VERTBAR:| bold-p VERTBAR:| RELOP:equals italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start F POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start VERTBAR:parallel-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start ARG:end RELOP:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where N‚Å¢(0)ùëÅ0italic-N OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)N(0) is the density of states at the Fermi level. The Pauli limit HPsubscriptùêªPitalic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start P POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{H_{\rm P}} for anisotropic pairing is calculated by

semantics.annotation: italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start P POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-square-root ARG:start OPEN:langle OPEN:[ italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OVERACCENT:hat ARG:start bold-p ARG:end CLOSE:) CLOSE:] POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle ARG:end ARG:end ARG:start OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start Delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end ARG:end

div.p: with

semantics.annotation: FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end RELOP:equals OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPEN:langle OPEN:[ italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OVERACCENT:hat ARG:start bold-p ARG:end CLOSE:) CLOSE:] POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPFUNCTION:logarithm OPEN:[ NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide VERTBAR:| italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OVERACCENT:hat ARG:start bold-p ARG:end CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| CLOSE:] CLOSE:rangle ARG:end ARG:start OPEN:langle OPEN:[ italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OVERACCENT:hat ARG:start bold-p ARG:end CLOSE:) CLOSE:] POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle ARG:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: In the above equations, the vector ùê™ùê™bold-q{{\bf q}} is the center-of-mass momentum of Cooper pairs of the FFLO state. From the symmetry of the system, there are four or eight equivalent optimum vectors (ùê™msubscriptùê™ùëöbold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{{\bf q}}_{m}‚Äôs), depending on whether ùê™ùê™bold-q{{\bf q}} is in a symmetry direction or not, respectively. Actually, arbitrary linear combination of exp‚Å°(i‚Å¢ùê™m‚ãÖùê´)‚ãÖisubscriptùê™ùëöùê´OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( i bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:cdot bold-r CLOSE:)\exp({\rm i}{{\bf q}}_{m}\cdot{{\bf r}}) gives the same second order critical field, and the degeneracy is removed by the nonlinear term of the gap equation below the critical field¬†[7, 16]. However, regarding the critical field and the optimum direction of the oscillation of the order parameter near the critical field, it is sufficient to take a single ùê™ùê™bold-q{{\bf q}} as in eq.(3).

Figures 2 and 3 show numerical results of the critical fields for t2=-0.6subscriptùë°20.6italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.6t_{2}=-0.6, with our previous results for t2=0subscriptùë°20italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0t_{2}=0 (dotted lines)¬†[12]. It is found that the critical fields are remarkably enhanced near the electron densities n‚âà1.46ùëõ1.46italic-n RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1.46n\approx 1.46 and 1.201.20NUMBER:1.201.20 for the sùë†italic-ss-wave and the dùëëitalic-dd-wave pairing, respectively. For example, at the electron density n=1.1ùëõ1.1italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.1n=1.1, the ratios of the critical field to the Pauli paramagnetic limit are approximately equal to 1.66 and 3.19 for the sùë†italic-ss-wave and the dùëëitalic-dd-wave pairing, respectively. These values (especially the latter) seem to be large enough to make the coexistence possible in RuSr2‚Å¢GdCu2‚Å¢O8subscriptRuSr2subscriptGdCu2subscriptO8RuSr POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end GdCu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end O POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm RuSr_{2}GdCu_{2}O_{8}}.

In Fig.3 for the dùëëitalic-dd-wave pairing, both the critical fields for œÜùê™=œÄ/4subscriptùúëùê™ùúã4italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\varphi_{{{\bf q}}}=\pi/4 and œÜùê™=0subscriptùúëùê™0italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\varphi_{{{\bf q}}}=0 are shown, but the highest one is the final result of the critical field given by eq.(4). Here, œÜùê™subscriptùúëùê™italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\varphi_{{{\bf q}}} is the angle between the optimum ùê™ùê™bold-q{{\bf q}} and one of the crystal axes. It is shown by a numerical calculation that the critical fields for the other values of œÜùê™subscriptùúëùê™italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\varphi_{{{\bf q}}} are lower than the higher one of the critical fields for œÜùê™=œÄ/4subscriptùúëùê™ùúã4italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\varphi_{{{\bf q}}}=\pi/4 and 0. Thus, the direction of the optimum wave vector ùê™ùê™bold-q{{\bf q}} jumps from œÜùê™=œÄ/4subscriptùúëùê™ùúã4italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\varphi_{{{\bf q}}}=\pi/4 to œÜùê™=0subscriptùúëùê™0italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\varphi_{{{\bf q}}}=0 at n‚âà1.63ùëõ1.63italic-n RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1.63n\approx 1.63. On the other hand, for the sùë†italic-ss-wave pairing, œÜùê™=œÄ/4subscriptùúëùê™ùúã4italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\varphi_{{{\bf q}}}=\pi/4 is the optimum in the whole region of the electron density. These behaviors are different from that for t2=0subscriptùë°20italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0t_{2}=0, in which œÜùê™=0subscriptùúëùê™0italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\varphi_{{{\bf q}}}=0¬†[12].

For t2=-0.6subscriptùë°20.6italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.6t_{2}=-0.6, a cusp is seen in Fig.2 for the sùë†italic-ss-wave pairing, whereas it does not appear in Fig.3 for the dùëëitalic-dd-wave pairing. The physical origin of the cusp at n‚âà1.46ùëõ1.46italic-n RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1.46n\approx 1.46 is that the Fermi surfaces satisfy a certain condition there, which was explained in our previous paper for t2=0subscriptùë°20italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0t_{2}=0¬†[12]. It is related to how the two Fermi-surfaces touch by the translation by the optimum ùê™ùê™bold-q{{\bf q}}. In the present case (t2=-0.6subscriptùë°20.6italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.6t_{2}=-0.6 and n‚âà1.46ùëõ1.46italic-n RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1.46n\approx 1.46), the touch occurs in the (110) direction, but because of the nodes of the order parameter the ‚Äúnesting‚Äù is not efficient for the dùëëitalic-dd-wave pairing. Therefore, cusp does not appear for the dùëëitalic-dd-wave pairing.

img.figcaption: Figure 2: Critical fields of the FFLO state of the sùë†italic-ss-wave pairing for n=0.92‚àº2ùëõ0.92similar-to2italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.92 RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:2n=0.92\sim 2 at T=0ùëá0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0. Solid and broken lines show the results for t2=-0.6subscriptùë°20.6italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.6t_{2}=-0.6 and t2=0subscriptùë°20italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0t_{2}=0, respectively.

Figure 3: Critical fields of the FFLO state of the dùëëitalic-dd-wave pairing for n=0.92‚àº2ùëõ0.92similar-to2italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.92 RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:2n=0.92\sim 2 at T=0ùëá0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0. Solid and broken lines show the results for œÜùê™=œÄ/4subscriptùúëùê™ùúã4italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\varphi_{{{\bf q}}}=\pi/4 and œÜùê™=0subscriptùúëùê™0italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\varphi_{{{\bf q}}}=0, respectively, when t2=-0.6subscriptùë°20.6italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.6t_{2}=-0.6. The dotted line shows the result for t2=0subscriptùë°20italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0t_{2}=0. Thin solid line and thin dotted line show the Pauli paramagnetic limits in the unit of Œîd‚Å¢0subscriptŒîùëë0Delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta_{d0}, for t2=-0.6subscriptùë°20.6italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.6t_{2}=-0.6 and 00NUMBER:0, respectively.

div.p: In spite of the absence of cusp behavior, the critical field is still very large for the dùëëitalic-dd-wave pairing near the half-filling. Figure 4 shows the nesting behavior of the Fermi-surfaces at t2=-0.6subscriptùë°20.6italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.6t_{2}=-0.6 and n=1.1ùëõ1.1italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.1n=1.1. The direction of the optimum vector ùê™ùê™bold-q{{\bf q}} is œÜùê™=œÄ/4subscriptùúëùê™ùúã4italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\varphi_{{{\bf q}}}=\pi/4, and the Fermi-surfaces touch at two points (i.e., two lines in the px‚Å¢py‚Å¢pzsubscriptùëùùë•subscriptùëùùë¶subscriptùëùùëßitalic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:endp_{x}p_{y}p_{z}-space), (px,py)‚âà(1.113‚Å¢œÄ,1.713‚Å¢œÄ)subscriptùëùùë•subscriptùëùùë¶1.113ùúã1.713ùúãOPEN:( italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:approximately-equals OPEN:( NUMBER:1.113 italic-pi PUNCT:, NUMBER:1.713 italic-pi CLOSE:)(p_{x},p_{y})\approx(1.113\pi,1.713\pi) and (1.713‚Å¢œÄ,1.113‚Å¢œÄ)1.713ùúã1.113ùúãOPEN:( NUMBER:1.713 italic-pi PUNCT:, NUMBER:1.113 italic-pi CLOSE:)(1.713\pi,1.113\pi). Since œÜùê™=œÄ/4subscriptùúëùê™ùúã4italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\varphi_{{{\bf q}}}=\pi/4 is also the direction of a node of the dùëëitalic-dd-wave order parameter, it may appear that this direction is less favorable. However, in actuality the critical field is remarkably enhanced for this ‚Äúnesting‚Äù vector ùê™ùê™bold-q{{\bf q}}, since it gives two nesting lines which are far away from the nodes but near the flattest areas, as shown in Fig.4. Besides, they are near both the maxima of the dùëëitalic-dd-wave order parameter and the van Hove singularities, which also enhance the critical field. As the electron density increases, the two nesting lines approach to the line node of the order parameter, and thus the critical field decreases.

img.figcaption: Figure 4: Fermi-surface nesting for the FFLO state and the optimum wave vector ùê™ùê™bold-q{{\bf q}} of the FFLO state at the critical field (hc=1.87‚Å¢Œîd‚Å¢0subscript‚Ñéc1.87subscriptŒîùëë0italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.87 Delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endh_{\rm c}=1.87\Delta_{d0}) at n=1.1ùëõ1.1italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.1n=1.1. Solid and broken lines show the Fermi-surfaces of the up and down spin electrons, respectively. Dotted line shows the Fermi-surface of the down spin electrons shifted by ùê™ùê™bold-q{{\bf q}}. Small arrows show the wave vector ùê™ùê™bold-q{{\bf q}}. They are placed at the momenta at which the two Fermi-surfaces touch. Dotted broken lines show the nodes of the dùëëitalic-dd-wave order parameter. We use a large value of Œîd‚Å¢0=0.3‚Å¢t/1.87subscriptŒîùëë00.3ùë°1.87Delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.3 italic-t MULOP:divide NUMBER:1.87\Delta_{d0}=0.3t/1.87 (i.e., hc=0.3‚Å¢tsubscript‚Ñéc0.3ùë°italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.3 italic-th_{\rm c}=0.3t) in order to make the displacement visible.

div.p: Since the optimum direction œÜùê™=œÄ/4subscriptùúëùê™ùúã4italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\varphi_{{{\bf q}}}=\pi/4 is in a symmetry line, there are four equivalent directions, that is, œÜùê™=¬±œÄ/4subscriptùúëùê™plus-or-minusùúã4italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\varphi_{{{\bf q}}}=\pm\pi/4 and ¬±3‚Å¢œÄ/4plus-or-minus3ùúã4ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:3 italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\pm 3\pi/4. Therefore, symmetric linear combinations such as

semantics.annotation: ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start Delta OPEN:( bold-p PUNCT:, bold-r CLOSE:) CELL:end CELL:start RELOP:proportional-to CELL:end CELL:start TRIGFUNCTION:cosine OPEN:( italic-q italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start Delta OPEN:( bold-p PUNCT:, bold-r CLOSE:) CELL:end CELL:start RELOP:proportional-to CELL:end CELL:start TRIGFUNCTION:cosine OPEN:( italic-q italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus TRIGFUNCTION:cosine OPEN:( italic-q italic-y POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end

div.p: are convincing candidates, which may be observed in the present compound, where x‚Ä≤=(x+y)/2superscriptùë•‚Ä≤ùë•ùë¶2italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:( italic-x ADDOP:plus italic-y CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:endx^{\prime}=(x+y)/\sqrt{2} and y‚Ä≤=(x-y)/2superscriptùë¶‚Ä≤ùë•ùë¶2italic-y POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:( italic-x ADDOP:minus italic-y CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:endy^{\prime}=(x-y)/\sqrt{2}. In particular, the 2D structures such as the latter of eq.(11) are favored at high fields¬†[16].

For the FFLO state to appear, temperature needs to be lower than the tri-critical temperature T*superscriptùëáitalic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT^{*} of the FFLO, BCS and normal states. T*superscriptùëáitalic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT^{*} is generally equal to about 0.56‚Å¢Tc(0)0.56superscriptsubscriptùëác0NUMBER:0.56 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end0.56T_{\rm c}^{(0)} in simplified models such as eq.(5). If we apply this to the present system RuSr2‚Å¢GdCu2‚Å¢O8subscriptRuSr2subscriptGdCu2subscriptO8RuSr POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end GdCu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end O POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm RuSr_{2}GdCu_{2}O_{8}}, T*‚àº>Tc‚âà46‚Å¢Ksuperscriptsimilar-tosuperscriptùëásubscriptùëác46Kitalic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP ARG:start RELOP:similar-to ARG:end ARG:start RELOP:greater-than ARG:end RELOP:end italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:46 KT^{*}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle{\textstyle>}}}{{\raisebox{-3.225pt}{$\sim$}}}T_{% \rm c}\approx 46{\rm K} requires Tc(0)‚àº>82‚Å¢Ksuperscriptsimilar-tosuperscriptsubscriptùëác082Kitalic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP ARG:start RELOP:similar-to ARG:end ARG:start RELOP:greater-than ARG:end RELOP:end NUMBER:82 KT_{\rm c}^{(0)}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle{\textstyle>}}}{{\raisebox{-3.225pt}{$% \sim$}}}82{\rm K}. This condition for Tc(0)superscriptsubscriptùëác0italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT_{\rm c}^{(0)} may be relaxed by taking into account a mixing of order parameters of different symmetries, which increases T*superscriptùëáitalic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT^{*}¬†[17].

In conclusion, the FFLO critical field of the cuprate layers is remarkably enhanced by an effect of the Fermi-surface structure. The direction of the spatial oscillation of the order parameter is in the (110)110OPEN:( NUMBER:110 CLOSE:)(110) direction both for the sùë†italic-ss-wave pairing and the dùëëitalic-dd-wave pairing. Although we examined only the ground state in this paper, the result Hc/HP‚âà3.19subscriptùêªcsubscriptùêªP3.19italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start P POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:3.19H_{\rm c}/{H_{\rm P}}\approx 3.19 at T=0ùëá0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0 is large enough to support coexistence of the superconductivity and the ferromagnetic order in a microscopic scale in RuSr2‚Å¢GdCu2‚Å¢O8subscriptRuSr2subscriptGdCu2subscriptO8RuSr POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end GdCu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end O POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm RuSr_{2}GdCu_{2}O_{8}}. Calculation for finite temperatures is now in progress.
This work was supported by a grant for Core Research for Evolutionary Science and Technology (CREST) from Japan Science and Technology Corporation (JST).

In this paper we use the term ‚ÄúPauli paramagnetic limit‚Äù for the BCS state with zero center-of-mass momentum.
